::: {.hidden}
$$
\newcommand{\expr}[3]{\begin{array}{c}
#1 \\
\bbox[lightblue,5px]{#2}
\end{array} ⊢ #3}
\newcommand{\ct}[1]{\bbox[font-size: 0.8em]{\mathsf{#1}}}
\newcommand{\abbr}[1]{\bbox[transform: scale(0.95)]{\mathtt{#1}}}
\def\true{\ct{T}}
\def\false{\ct{F}}
$$
:::

To illustrate ditransitive verbs, let's consider the two sentences in (@ex-show).

(@ex-show) a. Po showed noodles to Tigress. <br>
	b. Po showed Tigress noodles.

These sentences, arguably, entail each other.
To capture this fact, we might assign the ditransitive verb *showed* two distinct lexical entries, as in (@ex-lexicon).

(@ex-lexicon) $⟨\textit{showed}, (λx.(λy.(λz.\ct{showed}(z, x, y))))⟩ ⊢ (((np\backslash s)/pp)/np)$ <br>
	$⟨\textit{showed}, (λy.(λx.(λz.\ct{showed}(z, x, y))))⟩ ⊢ (((np\backslash s)/np)/np)$
